case_vignette: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine checkup. He has had a progressively increasing swelling on the nape of his neck for 2 months. He does not have a fever or any discharge from the swelling. He underwent a colectomy for colon cancer at the age of 43 years. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoarthritis of the left knee. Current medications include insulin glargine, metformin, enalapril, and naproxen. He has worked as a traffic warden for the past 6 years and frequently plays golf. He appears healthy. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg. Examination of the neck shows a 2.5-cm (1-in) firm, mobile, and painless nodule. The skin over the nodule cannot be pinched. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the lesion is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

trial_4.summarized_conversation: A 55-year-old patient presents with a swelling on the back of their neck that has been steadily growing over the past two months. The swelling is not painful or tender, and the patient has not experienced fever, fatigue, or difficulty swallowing. The patient has a history of colon cancer surgery at age 43, type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, and arthritis in the left knee. There is no redness or discoloration of the skin around the swelling. The patient is currently taking insulin glargine, metformin, enalapril, and naproxen, and has not noticed any changes in bowel movements or urination. There have been no changes in posture or gait, and the patient has not experienced numbness or tingling in their face or limbs. No changes in breathing or shortness of breath have been noted, and the patient denies exposure to allergens or irritants that could cause the swelling. There have been no changes in vision, headaches, facial pain, skin redness, rashes, or lesions. The patient has not traveled or been exposed to new insects or pets. There have been no difficulties with swallowing or hoarseness, and no swelling or tenderness in the glands under the tongue or in the neck. Appetite and weight have remained stable, and there have been no recent changes in breathing or chest symptoms, coughing, or chest tightness. The patient has not experienced sore throat, neck or shoulder pain, and there have been no changes in voice or difficulty speaking.
